critique: This executive order, issued in 1946, extends the provisions of a previous order (EO 9177) related to the First War Powers Act to the Secretary of Commerce. It authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to perform functions and powers vested in other secretaries and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Given the context of the post-World War II era, this likely involves economic regulations and controls related to wartime powers. There's no direct indication of ideological tilt, immigration, or social inclusion. The order expands executive power by delegating authority to the Secretary of Commerce. It also centralizes power at the federal level. The order seems to prioritize economic regulation and potentially national security (given the context of the War Powers Act) over civil liberties. There's no clear indication of social inclusion or conformity.
